questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress, a scaphoid abdomen, and cyanosis shortly after birth. What is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
CDH Management Algorithm :

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)

Definition: A defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity.

Epidemiology

  • Bochdalek Hernia: Most common type (~85%), typically left-sided. The defect is posterolateral.
  • Morgagni Hernia: Anterior, less common.
  • Incidence: 1 in 2000-5000 live births

Clinical Presentation

  • Respiratory distress shortly after birth
  • Scaphoid abdomen: Sunken appearance of the abdomen due to herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax
  • Cyanosis
  • Decreased breath sounds on the affected side

Diagnosis

  • Prenatal: Ultrasound may detect polyhydramnios and abdominal contents in the thorax.
  • Postnatal: Chest x-ray showing bowel loops in the thorax and mediastinal shift.

Complications

  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN)

Management

  • Initial: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation
  • Subsequent: Nasogastric tube placement for decompression
  • Definitive: Surgical repair after stabilisation of pulmonary and cardiac function

Surgical Options

  • Primary repair of the diaphragmatic defect
  • Use of a patch for larger defects

Option A : Immediate surgical repair is necessary but not the first step.

Option B : Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the condition by inflating the stomach and intestines, worsening respiratory compromise.

Option C : Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are crucial to stabilise the patient and manage respiratory distress.

Option D :  Nasogastric tube placement is also necessary to decompress the stomach but follows intubation and ventilation.

Key Takeaways  :

  • CDH typically presents with respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen.
  • Initial management involves stabilisation with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • Definitive treatment is surgical repair once the patient is stabilised.
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia is the most common cause of death in CDH.

questions.text: A full term neonate presents with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. An abdominal Xray shows dilated loops of bowel with a ground glass appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Meconium Ileus

Pathophysiology:

  • Meconium ileus is primarily caused by thick, sticky meconium obstructing the ileum.
  • It is most often associated with cystic fibrosis.

Clinical Features:

  • Abdominal distension is a common symptom.
  • Failure to pass meconium within 48 hours of birth is a key sign.
  • Vomiting can occur, especially if the obstruction is distal.

Diagnosis:

  • Abdominal X-ray shows dilated bowel loops with a ground glass or soap bubble appearance due to inspissated meconium.
  • Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic, showing a microcolon and potentially dislodging the meconium.

Management:

  • Contrast enema is the initial treatment to relieve the obstruction.
  • Surgical intervention may be necessary if the enema fails or if complications arise.

Complications:

  • Volvulus is a surgical emergency.
  • Perforation can lead to peritonitis.

Option A : Hirschsprung disease presents with delayed meconium passage and a distended abdomen, but the X Ray findings described are more characteristic of meconium ileus.

Option B : Meconium ileus, Contrast enema is Correct. Meconium ileus is associated with cystic fibrosis and presents with a characteristic "ground glass" appearance on X Ray. A contrast enema can be both diagnostic and therapeutic by helping to dislodge the thickened meconium.

Option C : Intestinal atresia presents with bilious vomiting and double bubble sign on Xray, not with the ground glass appearance described here.

Option D : Meconium plug syndrome also presents with delayed passage of meconium, but the ground glass appearance is more specific for meconium ileus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Meconium ileus is commonly associated with cystic fibrosis and presents with a characteristic ground glass appearance on X Ray.
  • Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic for meconium ileus.

questions.text: A 2 month old infant presents with jaundice, pale stools, and hepatomegaly. A liver biopsy shows bile duct proliferation and fibrosis. What is the first line surgical treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
BILIARY ATRESIA

Definition:

  • Progressive obliteration or absence of the extrahepatic bile ducts, leading to cholestasis and liver damage.

Classification:

  • Type I: Atresia of the common bile duct.
  • Type II: Atresia of the common hepatic duct.
  • Type III: Atresia of the right and left hepatic ducts to the level of the porta hepatis

Clinical Presentation:

  • Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks of age.
  • Pale or clay-coloured stools.
  • Dark urine.
  • Hepatomegaly.
  • Associated Symptoms: Failure to thrive, irritability due to pruritus from cholestasis.

Diagnosis:

  • HIDA scan: A nuclear medicine test to evaluate bile flow.

Complications:

  • Cirrhosis.
  • Portal hypertension.
  • Liver failure.

Management:

  • Initial: Kasai portoenterostomy (hepatoportoenterostomy).
  • Subsequent: Liver transplantation if the Kasai procedure fails.

Kasai Portoenterostomy:

  • Bypasses the atretic bile ducts by connecting the liver to the small intestine.

Option A : Liver transplantation is considered if the initial surgical treatment fails.

Option B : ERCP is not the primary treatment for biliary atresia.

Option C : Kasai portoenterostomy is the first line surgical treatment hence Correct Option.

Option D : Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is used for diagnostic purposes.

Key Takeaways :

  • EHBA typically presents with persistent jaundice, pale stools, and hepatomegaly.
  • Kasai portoenterostomy is the first line surgical treatment.
  • Liver transplantation is considered if the Kasai procedure is unsuccessful.
  • Type III is the most common form of EHBA.

questions.text: A newborn presents with exposed abdominal contents at birth. The intestines are not covered by a sac and are protruding to the right of the umbilical cord. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Major Difference between Exomphalos & Gastroschisis



Option A : Gastroschisis is characterised by intestines protruding through a defect to the right of the umbilical cord without a covering sac. hence Option A Is Correct.

Option B : Omphalocele involves abdominal contents protruding through the umbilical cord covered by a sac.

Option C : Umbilical hernia involves protrusion through the umbilical ring, covered by skin.

Option D : Diaphragmatic hernia involves abdominal contents herniating into the thorax, not externally.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gastroschisis: Defect to the right of the umbilical cord, no sac.
  • Omphalocele: Defect at the umbilical cord, covered by a sac.
  • Management: Both require surgical intervention; omphaloceles may need staged repair due to associated anomalies.

choices.text: Type B (esophageal atresia with proximal fistula)
Type C (esophageal atresia with distal fistula)
Type D (esophageal atresia with double fistula)

questions.text: A newborn presents with excessive salivation, choking, and cyanosis during feeding. An X ray shows a coiled nasogastric tube in the upper esophageal pouch. What is the most likely type of tracheo esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
• A newborn presents with excessive salivation, choking, and cyanosis during feeding suggest Distal Fistula
  • An X ray shows a coiled nasogastric tube in the upper esophageal pouch. suggest esophageal atresia Hence Option C is Correct.

TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA Summary :


Option A : Isolated esophageal atresia (Type A) does not have a fistula.

Option B : Type B has a fistula from the proximal oesophagus to the trachea.

Option C : Type C is the most common, with esophageal atresia and a distal fistula.

Option D : Type D has both proximal and distal fistulas.

Key Takeaways:

  • Most common type: Type C (esophageal atresia with distal fistula).
  • Initial management: Stabilisation with suctioning of secretions.
  • Key diagnostic tool: X ray showing coiled nasogastric tube and air in the stomach.
  • Common complications: Aspiration pneumonia, respiratory distress.
  • Surgical repair: Primary anastomosis or staged repair.

choices.text: Rectal biopsy followed by pull through surgery
Anorectal manometry followed by anal dilation

questions.text: A 2 month old infant presents with a history of chronic constipation, abdominal distension, and failure to thrive. Digital rectal examination reveals an empty rectum. What is the definitive diagnostic test, and what is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Hirschsprung Disease

Pathophysiology:

  • Congenital absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal (Meissner) and myenteric (Auerbach) plexuses of the distal colon, leading to a functional obstruction.
  • Caused by a failure of neural crest cells to migrate during foetal development.

Clinical Features:

  • Failure to Pass Meconium: A key early sign, typically within the first 48 hours of life.
  • Chronic Constipation
  • Abdominal Distension and Vomiting
  • Empty Rectum on Digital Examination: Despite the presence of stool in the proximal colon, the rectum remains empty.
  • Enterocolitis

Diagnosis:

  • Rectal Biopsy: The gold standard for diagnosis, revealing the absence of ganglion cells.
  • Barium Enema: May show a transition zone between the dilated, ganglionic segment and the narrow, aganglionic segment.

Management:

  • Preoperative Care: Managing enterocolitis, hydration, and correcting fluid/electrolyte imbalances.
    • Surgical Treatment:
      • Pull-Through Procedure: Various techniques are used, including:
      • Swenson Procedure: Resecting the aganglionic segment and anastomosing normal bowel to the anal canal.
      • Soave Procedure: Preserving the mucosa of the aganglionic segment and pulling normal bowel through.
      • Duhamel Procedure: Leaving the aganglionic segment in situ and creating a side-to-side anastomosis.

Complications:

  • Enterocolitis: The most feared complication.
  • Strictures: May develop at the anastomotic site.
  • Anastomotic Leaks: A potential postoperative complication.

Option A : Barium enema followed by observation is incorrect. Barium enema can reveal a transition zone between the dilated proximal colon and the narrow aganglionic segment, but this is not definitive for diagnosis. Observation alone is not sufficient.

Option B : Rectal biopsy followed by pull through surgery is correct. Rectal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing Hirschsprung disease, showing the absence of ganglion cells. The definitive treatment is a pull through surgery, which involves resection of the aganglionic segment and anastomosis of the normal bowel to the anus.

Option C : Anorectal manometry followed by anal dilation is incorrect. Anorectal manometry can suggest Hirschsprung disease by showing an absence of the rectoanal inhibitory reflex, but this is not definitive. Anal dilation is not appropriate as it does not address the underlying problem.

Option D : Colonoscopy followed by stoma creation is incorrect. Colonoscopy is not a diagnostic tool for Hirschsprung disease, and stoma creation is not the initial management step unless there are complications such as enterocolitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rectal biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test for Hirschsprung disease.
  • Pull through surgery is the standard treatment, with several techniques available based on the surgeon’s preference and the patient’s anatomy.

choices.text: Ultrasound of the abdomen and observation

questions.text: A 6 month old male presents with an intermittent bulge in the groin, which becomes more prominent when crying. On examination, a reducible mass is palpated in the inguinal region. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Paediatric Inguinal Hernia

Incidence:

  • More common in boys, often on the right side.
  • Approximately 15% in term infants, higher in preterm

Pathophysiology:

  • Failure of the processus vaginalis to close, allowing abdominal contents to protrude through the inguinal canal.

A congenital defect, unlike adult hernias, which are often acquired.

Clinical Features:

  • Intermittent Groin Swelling: The most common presentation, often more noticeable when the infant is crying or straining.
  • Incarceration
  • Strangulation

Diagnosis:

  • Physical Examination: Typically sufficient to diagnose inguinal hernias. The reducible groin mass is a classic finding.
  • Ultrasound: May be used if the diagnosis is unclear or to distinguish between hernias and other causes of groin swelling.

Management:

  • Elective Surgical Repair (Inguinal Herniotomy): Recommended to prevent the risk of incarceration or strangulation. The surgery involves ligation and excision of the hernia sac.
  • Emergency Surgery: Required if there is incarceration with or without strangulation.

Option A : Observation and follow up is incorrect. Observation is not recommended as the risk of incarceration is significant, especially in infants.

Option B : Elective surgical repair is Correct. Inguinal hernias in children should be repaired electively to prevent complications such as incarceration or strangulation.

Option C : Immediate manual reduction and discharge is incorrect. Manual reduction may be required in cases of incarcerated hernias, but elective surgical repair should follow.

Option D : Ultrasound of the abdomen and observation is incorrect. Ultrasound may help in cases where the diagnosis is uncertain, but observation alone is not appropriate.

Key Takeaways:

  • Elective surgical repair is recommended for all paediatric inguinal hernias to prevent complications.
  • Incarceration and strangulation are potential risks that necessitate timely intervention.

questions.text: A 1 year old boy is brought in by his parents because they have noticed that one of his testes has not descended into the scrotum. On examination, the right testis is palpable in the inguinal canal. What is the best management option at this point?
questions.solution:
Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Incidence:

  • Approximately 4% in full-term male infants, up to 30% in preterm infants.
  • Most descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Pathophysiology:

  • Failure of one or both testes to descend into the scrotum.
  • Can lead to infertility, increased risk of testicular malignancy, and testicular torsion if not corrected.

Clinical Features:

  • Absent Testis in the Scrotum: The most obvious sign, usually detected during a routine physical exam.
  • Palpable Testis: May be located in the inguinal canal, high in the scrotum, or, in some cases, nonpalpable (intraabdominal).

Diagnosis:

  • Physical Examination: The primary method of diagnosis. The location of the testis can often be determined by palpation.
  • Ultrasound or MRI: May be used to locate non palpable testes, although their utility is limited.

Management:

  • Elective Orchidopexy: The standard treatment, usually performed between 6 months and 1 year of age. Involves mobilising the testis and securing it in the scrotum.
  • Hormonal Therapy: Generally not recommended due to limited success rates and potential side effects.
  • Orchiectomy: Considered in older patients with intra abdominal testes due to the increased risk of malignancy.

Complications:

  • Infertility
  • Testicular Malignancy
  • Testicular Torsion

Option A : Observation until 2 years of age is incorrect. Observation beyond 6 months is not recommended because spontaneous descent is unlikely after this age.

Option B : Hormonal therapy with hCG is incorrect. Hormonal therapy has limited success and is generally not the first line treatment.

Option C : Elective orchidopexy is Correct. Orchidopexy is the standard treatment, usually performed between 6 months and 1 year of age to reduce the risk of infertility and malignancy.

Option D : Immediate orchiectomy is incorrect.  Orchiectomy is not indicated unless there is a suspicion of malignancy, typically in older patients or those with intra abdominal testes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Orchidopexy should be performed between 6 months and 1 year of age for undescended testes to minimise the risk of infertility and malignancy.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presents with acute scrotal pain and a tender, blue coloured nodule on the upper pole of the testis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Torsion of the appendix testis

Definition:

  • The twisting of a small vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Acute scrotal pain
  • Tender blue-coloured nodule on the upper pole of the testis (blue dot sign)

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical examination
  • Doppler ultrasound to rule out testicular torsion

Complications:

  • Secondary infection
  • Scrotal abscess

Management:

  • Conservative treatment with analgesics and rest
  • Surgical exploration if diagnosis is uncertain or symptoms persist.

Option A: Testicular torsion presents with sudden onset severe scrotal pain and a high riding testis.

Option B: Torsion of the appendix testis presents with acute scrotal pain and a blue dot sign (tender blue coloured nodule on the upper pole of the testis).Hence Correct Option.

Option C: Epididymitis presents with gradual onset scrotal pain and swelling.

Option D: Hydrocele presents with painless scrotal swelling.

Key Takeaways :

  • Blue dot sign is indicative of torsion of the appendix testis.
  • Conservative treatment is usually sufficient.

choices.text: Intravenous fluids and electrolyte correction followed by surgery

questions.text: A 4 week old male infant presents with nonbilious projectile vomiting and a palpable olive shaped mass in the epigastrium. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (HPS)

Incidence:

  • Approximately 1 in 300 to 1 in 500 live births.
  • More common in firstborn males.

Aetiology:

  • Hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle leads to gastric outlet obstruction.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Projectile Nonbilious Vomiting: Typically occurs after feeding.
  • Palpable Olive-Shaped Mass: Found in the right upper quadrant or epigastric, most evident during or after feeding.
  • Visible Gastric Peristalsis: A wave of contraction moving from left to right across the abdomen.
  • Metabolic Disturbances: Hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Preferred diagnostic tool, showing pyloric muscle thickness >4 mm and channel length >16 mm.
  • Barium Meal: May show the "string sign," but this is typically used if the ultrasound is inconclusive.

Management:

  • Initial Stabilisation:
    • Correction of Dehydration and Electrolyte Abnormalities: Use IV fluids with normal saline and potassium to correct metabolic alkalosis.
  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Ramstedt's Pyloromyotomy: The standard treatment, where the hypertrophic pyloric muscle is cut longitudinally while preserving the mucosa.

Option A : Immediate surgical intervention is incorrect. While surgery is required, it is not the immediate first step. Initial management involves stabilising the patient by correcting dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

Option B : Ultrasound of the abdomen is incorrect. Although ultrasound is the diagnostic tool of choice, it is not a management step. The diagnosis is already suggested by clinical signs (olive shaped mass).

Option C : Intravenous fluids and electrolyte correction followed by surgery is  Correct. The first step in management involves correcting hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis before performing surgery.

Option D : Upper GI series is incorrect. This is an alternative diagnostic option if the ultrasound is inconclusive, but it is not the first step in management.

Key Takeaways:

  • Always correct metabolic imbalances before proceeding with surgery in cases of HPS.

questions.text: A 9 month old infant presents with intermittent severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and the passage of red currant jelly stools. An abdominal ultrasound reveals a target sign. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Intussusception

Pathophysiology:

  • Intussusception occurs when a part of the intestine telescopes into an adjacent segment, leading to obstruction and possible ischemia.
  • The most common type is ileocolic intussusception.

Clinical Features:

  • Classic Triad: Sudden onset of episodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools (blood and mucus).
  • Dance Sign: Absence of bowel sounds or mass in the right lower quadrant, replaced by a palpable mass.
  • Sausage-Shaped Mass: Often palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium.
  • Red Currant Jelly Stools: Indicative of ischemia and mucosal sloughing.

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Preferred imaging modality; reveals the "target sign" or "doughnut sign."
  • Radiography (Barium or Air Enema): Diagnostic and therapeutic; reveals the "coiled spring sign."

Management:

  • NonSurgical Reduction: Air or barium enema is the treatment of choice, with success rates of over 70%.
  • Surgical Intervention: Indicated if nonsurgical reduction fails, if there are signs of perforation, or if the patient is unstable.

Complications:

  • Recurrence: Occurs in 5% of cases; may require repeat enema or surgical intervention.
  • Perforation: A risk during enema reduction, necessitating immediate surgery.

Option A : Exploratory laparotomy is reserved for cases where nonsurgical reduction fails, or if there are signs of perforation or peritonitis.

Option B : While IV fluids are essential, observation alone is not sufficient. Immediate intervention with air or barium enema is required for both diagnosis and treatment.

Option C : Air or barium enema reduction is the correct option. This is the first line treatment for intussusception. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic, with a high success rate in children.

Option D : Antibiotics alone are not the initial treatment for intussusception. They may be used if there is evidence of infection or perforation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Air or barium enema is the first line treatment for intussusception Which Presents with the classic triad of abdominal pain, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis is S/o of Acute Appendicitis.

Ddx of Abdominal Pain :

Option A : Intussusception typically presents with intermittent abdominal pain and bloody stools.

Option B : Acute appendicitis presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis.

Option C : Mesenteric adenitis can mimic appendicitis but often has more generalised abdominal pain & associated Lymphadenopathy.

Option D : Meckel's diverticulitis is rare and presents with painless bleeding or obstruction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute appendicitis is a common cause of right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. Definitive treatment is appendectomy

questions.text: A 1 month old infant presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension with the following xray . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duodenal Atresia

Definition:

  • Congenital obstruction of the duodenum, typically due to a failure of recanalization.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Bilious vomiting
  • Abdominal distension

Diagnosis:

  • Prenatal: Polyhydramnios on ultrasound
  • Postnatal: Abdominal x-ray or upper GI series showing the "double bubble" sign

Complications:

  • Dehydration
  • Electrolyte imbalances

Management:

  • Initial: Stabilisation with IV fluids and electrolyte correction
  • Definitive: Surgical repair (duodenoduodenostomy or duodenojejunostomy)

Option A : Duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting and a "double bubble" sign on imaging.

Option B : Intussusception presents with intermittent abdominal pain and bloody stools.

Option C : Hirschsprung disease presents with chronic constipation and abdominal distension.

Option D : Pyloric stenosis presents with non bilious projectile vomiting and a palpable olive shaped mass.

Key Takeaways:

  • Duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting and a "double bubble" sign on imaging. Definitive treatment is Duodenoduodenostomy.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with jejunal atresia. What is the classification stage of this condition based on the number of atretic segments and their separation?
questions.solution:
Type IV having Multiple Atresia is Dependent on number of atretic Segments & Their Separation.

Jejunal Atresia

Definition:

  • A congenital obstruction of the jejunum due to failure of recanalization or vascular accidents.

Classification:

  • Type I: Membranous atresia.
  • Type II: Fibrous cord connecting blind ending segments.
  • Type III: Mesenteric gap between blind ending segments.
  • Type IV: Multiple atresias ("string of sausages").

Clinical Presentation:

  • Bilious vomiting
  • Abdominal distension

Diagnosis:

  • Prenatal: Polyhydramnios on ultrasound
  • Postnatal: Abdominal x-ray showing dilated bowel loops

Complications:

  • Dehydration
  • Electrolyte imbalances

Management:

  • Initial: Stabilisation with IV fluids and electrolyte correction
  • Definitive: Surgical resection of the atretic segments and primary anastomosis

Option A : Type I: Membranous atresia without interruption of the bowel continuity.

Option B : Type II: Two blind ending bowel segments connected by a fibrous cord.

Option C : Type IIIa: Two blind ending bowel segments with a mesenteric gap.

Option D : Type IV: Multiple atresias, often referred to as a "string of sausages."

Key Takeaways:

  • Jejunal atresia presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.
  • Multiple atresias (Type IV) require surgical resection and anastomosis.

questions.text: A newborn presents with a large sacrococcygeal mass. Imaging reveals a solid and cystic tumour extending into the presacral space. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sacrococcygeal Teratoma

Definition:

  • A germ cell tumour arising from the coccyx.

Types:

  • Type I: Predominantly external, with minimal presacral component.
  • Type II: External with a significant intrapelvic extension.
  • Type III: External with significant abdominal and pelvic extension.
  • Type IV: Entirely internal, primarily presacral.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Visible mass at the sacrococcygeal region
  • May cause bowel or bladder obstruction

Diagnosis:

  • Prenatal: Ultrasound can detect a mass.
  • Postnatal: MRI or CT scan to assess the extent of the tumour.

Complications:

  • Malignant transformation
  • Obstructive symptoms

Management:

  • Surgical resection of the tumour, including the coccyx.

Option A : Sacrococcygeal teratoma presenting as a solid and cystic mass over back.

Option B : Neuroblastoma typically presents with an abdominal mass and may metastasize to the bone marrow.

Option C : Rhabdomyosarcoma presents as a soft tissue mass, usually in the head and neck or genitourinary tract.

Option D :  Wilms tumour presents as an abdominal mass, typically in the kidney.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma presents as a Solid or Cystic mass at the sacrococcygeal region and requires surgical resection.
  • Imaging is crucial to assess & manage the extent of the tumour.

choices.text: Spinal cord injury without radiographic abnormality (SCIWORA)

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with neck pain and decreased range of motion after a minor trauma. MRI shows no bony injury but indicates spinal cord edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality (SCIWORA)

Definition:

  • SCIWORA refers to spinal cord injury with no bony or ligamentous injury visible on radiographs or CT scans.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Neck pain
  • Decreased range of motion
  • Neurological deficits

Diagnosis:

  • MRI to detect spinal cord edema or hemorrhage
  • Clinical examination correlating with imaging findings

Complications:

  • Persistent neurological deficits
  • Chronic pain

Management:

  • Initial: Immobilization and corticosteroids
  • Long-term: Physical therapy and rehabilitation.

Option A : SCIWORA is diagnosed when there is clinical evidence of spinal cord injury without visible bony injury on X rays.

Option B : Vertebral fracture would show bony abnormalities on imaging.

Option C : Spinal cord tumour would present with a mass on imaging.

Option D : Disc herniation would show a disc abnormality on MRI.

Key Takeaways:

  • SCIWORA is a diagnosis of exclusion requiring MRI for confirmation.
  • Initial management includes immobilisation and corticosteroids.
  • Long term rehabilitation is essential for recovery.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) after a prenatal ultrasound revealed a multicystic mass in the lung. Postnatal imaging confirms the diagnosis. What is the best management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Congenital Lung Malformations

Types:

  • Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (CCAM): A multicystic mass of abnormal lung tissue that can vary in size and appearance.
  • Bronchopulmonary Sequestration: Nonfunctioning lung tissue that does not communicate with the bronchial tree and has an abnormal blood supply.
  • Congenital Lobar Emphysema: Overexpansion of a lobe of the lung, leading to compression of adjacent lung tissue.

Clinical Features:

  • Prenatal Diagnosis: Many cases of CCAM and other pulmonary malformations are detected on prenatal ultrasound.
  • Asymptomatic at Birth: Most infants with CCAM are asymptomatic at birth.
  • Respiratory Distress: Some may present with respiratory distress if the lesion is large or if there is associated hydrops fetalis.

Diagnosis:

  • Prenatal Ultrasound: Detects cystic or solid lung lesions.
  • Postnatal Imaging (Chest X-ray, CT Scan): Confirms the diagnosis and assesses the size and extent of the lesion.

Management:

  • Observation and Follow-up: Asymptomatic infants are often managed conservatively with regular imaging to monitor the lesion.
  • Surgical Resection: Indicated if the lesion is symptomatic, if there is rapid growth, or if there is a risk of malignancy (e.g., in CPAM/CCAM).
  • Antibiotics: Used if there is evidence of infection in the lesion, though this is rare.

Complications:

  • Respiratory Distress: Can occur if the lesion is large enough to compress normal lung tissue.
  • Infection: Rare, but possible in cystic lesions.
  • Malignant Transformation: Rarely, like pleuropulmonary blastoma.

Option A : Immediate surgical resection  is not always necessary immediately after birth. Many cases of CCAM are asymptomatic at birth and may be managed conservatively.

Option B : Observation and followup is Correct. For asymptomatic infants with CCAM, observation and regular followup are recommended, with surgery considered if symptoms develop or if the lesion grows.

Option C : Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a secondary infection.

Option D ::Corticosteroids have no role  in the management of CCAM.

Key Takeaways:

  • CCAM is often managed with observation and follow up, with surgery reserved for symptomatic cases or lesions with rapid growth.
  • Regular imaging is important to monitor for changes in the lesion that may require intervention.

choices.text: Grade III, Antibiotic prophylaxis and surgical intervention if recurrent UTIs

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) shows contrast reflux into the ureters and the renal pelvis, with moderate dilation of the ureters. What is the most likely grade of vesicoureteral reflux, and what is the recommended management?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)

Incidence:

  • Found in about 1% of children, more common in females.
  • Often discovered after a child presents with a urinary tract infection (UTI).

Grading of VUR (International Classification):

  • Grade I: Reflux into the ureter only, without dilation.
  • Grade II: Reflux into the renal pelvis without dilation.
  • Grade III: Reflux with mild to moderate dilation of the ureter and renal pelvis.
  • Grade IV: Reflux with moderate dilation and tortuosity of the ureter and renal pelvis.
  • Grade V: Severe dilation and tortuosity with loss of calyceal detail.

Clinical Features:

  • Recurrent UTIs: The most common presentation, especially in younger children.
  • Febrile UTIs: Often indicate pyelonephritis, which can lead to renal scarring.
  • Failure to Thrive: Chronic infections may lead to growth failure in severe cases.

Diagnosis:

  • Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG): The gold standard for diagnosing and grading VUR.
  • Renal Ultrasound: May show hydronephrosis or renal scarring but is not diagnostic for VUR.

Management:

  • Grades I-II: Typically managed with observation or low-dose antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent UTIs.
  • Grade III: Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended, with surgical intervention considered if there are recurrent UTIs or renal scarring.
  • Grades IV-V: Often require surgical correction, such as ureteral reimplantation, to prevent renal damage.

Surgical Procedures:

  • Ureteral Reimplantation: The most common surgery for high-grade VUR, which involves repositioning the ureters in the bladder to prevent reflux.
  • Endoscopic Injection of Bulking Agents: A less invasive option, used in some cases to correct reflux by injecting a bulking agent near the ureteral opening.

Option A : Grade I VUR involves reflux into a nondilated ureter and is often managed conservatively with observation.

Option B : Grade II involves reflux into the renal pelvis without dilation, and management usually includes antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent UTIs.

Option C : Grade III, Antibiotic prophylaxis and surgical intervention if recurrent UTIs is Correct. Grade III VUR involves moderate dilation of the ureter and renal pelvis. Management includes antibiotic prophylaxis, and surgical intervention is considered if there are recurrent UTIs or evidence of renal damage.

Option D : Grade IV and V VUR involve severe dilation and tortuosity of the ureters and renal pelvis, and surgery is often required, but initial management may still involve prophylaxis and monitoring.

Key Takeaways:

  • VUR is graded based on the severity of reflux and ureteral dilation, with management varying from observation to surgery depending on the grade.
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis is a key part of management for preventing recurrent UTIs in lower grades of VUR.

choices.text: Low Type imperforate anus, Immediate colostomy
High type imperforate anus, Delayed surgical correction after colostomy
Low Type imperforate anus, Immediate surgical repair (PSARP)
High type imperforate anus, Immediate surgical correction

questions.text: A newborn is found to have an absent anal opening. An invertogram performed after 24 hours shows the rectal gas at the level of the pubococcygeal line. What is the appropriate classification of this condition, and what is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Imperforate Anus

Incidence and Classification:

  • A congenital anomaly where the anal opening is absent or incorrectly positioned.
  • Low-type: Rectum ends below the levator ani muscle.
  • High-type: Rectum ends above the levator ani muscle.

Clinical Features:

  • Absence of Anal Opening: The most obvious sign at birth.
  • Associated Anomalies: Often occurs with other congenital defects, particularly in the sacrum, genitourinary system, and as part of VACTERL association.

Diagnosis:

  • Invertogram (24 hours post birth): Helps determine the level of the rectum in relation to the pubococcygeal line.
  • Ultrasound and MRI: Further imaging may be required to assess associated anomalies.

Management:

  • High-type: Initial colostomy to divert faecal flow, followed by Posterior Sagittal Anorectoplasty (PSARP) for definitive repair.
  • Low-type: Direct surgical correction, often without the need for a colostomy.

Surgical Procedures:

  • Posterior Sagittal Anorectoplasty (PSARP): The most common procedure used to repair both high and low anomalies.

Complications:

  • Faecal Incontinence
  • Strictures

Option A : Low type anomalies are managed with immediate surgical repair without the need for colostomy.

Option B : High type imperforate anus, Delayed surgical correction after colostomy is Correct. High type imperforate anus is characterised by the rectum ending above the levator ani muscle, and initial management involves colostomy to divert faecal flow, followed by definitive surgery (PSARP) at a later date.

Option C : Low Type imperforate anus, Immediate surgical repair (PSARP): This is the correct approach for low type anomalies, where the rectum is located below the pelvic floor.

Option D : Immediate surgical correction without a protective colostomy is inappropriate for high type anomalies due to the risk of complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • High type imperforate anus requires colostomy followed by delayed definitive surgical correction.
  • Invertogram is crucial for determining the level of the anomaly and guiding management.

choices.text: Broad spectrum antibiotics and bowel rest

questions.text: A 10 day old preterm infant presents with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and bloody stools. An abdominal Xray reveals pneumatosis intestinalis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC)

Pathophysiology:

  • Involves inflammation and bacterial invasion of the bowel wall, leading to necrosis.
  • The exact cause is multifactorial, involving gut immaturity, abnormal bacterial colonisation, and intestinal ischemia.

Risk Factors:

  • Prematurity: The most significant risk factor due to the immaturity of the gastrointestinal system.
  • Enteral Feeding: Particularly with formula, is associated with an increased risk.
  • Intestinal Ischemia: Conditions like hypotension or sepsis can reduce blood flow to the intestines.

Clinical Features:

  • Abdominal Distension: One of the earliest signs.
  • Bilious Vomiting: Indicative of high intestinal obstruction.
  • Bloody Stools: A sign of mucosal damage.
  • Feeding Intolerance: May present with gastric residuals or vomiting after feeding.
  • Systemic Signs: Apnea, bradycardia, lethargy, temperature instability, and signs of sepsis.

Diagnosis:

  • Abdominal X-ray: Key diagnostic tool showing pneumatosis intestinalis, which represents gas within the wall of the intestine. Other findings may include portal venous gas or free air under the diaphragm, indicating perforation.
  • Laboratory Findings: Nonspecific but may include metabolic acidosis, elevated white blood cell count, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy.

Modified Bell's Staging:

  • Stage I: Abdominal distension, feeding intolerance, vomiting, and lethargy.
  • Stage II : Pneumatosis Intestinalis
  • Stage IIIA : Ascites
  • Stage IIIB : Pneumoperitoneum

Management:

  • Medical Management:
    • Bowel Rest: Discontinue enteral feeds and provide parenteral nutrition.
    • Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics: Typically, a combination of ampicillin, gentamicin, and metronidazole or clindamycin.
    • Supportive Care: Includes IV fluids, electrolyte management, and monitoring for systemic signs of sepsis.
  • Surgical Management:
    • Indications: Perforation, failure of medical management, or worsening clinical condition.

Complications:

  • Short Bowel Syndrome
  • Strictures

Option A: Enteral feeding is contraindicated in NEC as it can exacerbate the condition.

Option B: Surgery may be needed if there is perforation or failure of medical management, but the initial step is usually conservative management.

Option C: Broad Spectrum antibiotics and bowel rest is Correct. The initial management of NEC involves stopping enteral feeds, providing bowel rest, and administering broad spectrum antibiotics to combat infection and stabilise the infant.

Option D: Perform an upper GI series diagnostic test is not appropriate in the acute setting of suspected NEC as it could delay treatment and worsen the condition.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis is the hallmark radiologic sign of NEC.
  • Broad Spectrum antibiotics and bowel rest are the first steps in management.
